channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin’s Draft Draws Resistance in Russia’s Far-Flung Regions
item.description: Villagers, activists and some elected officials asked why the conscription drive seemed to be hitting poor, remote areas hardest, while pro-war hawks criticized it as chaotic.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: On a Corpse’s Wrist, an Emblem of Ukrainian Fortitude
item.description: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators exhumed bodies at the site of a mass grave in Izium this month.

item.title: Stock Markets Tumble as Recession Fears Return
item.description: Central banks around the world raised interest rates this week to combat inflation. That’s raising concerns among investors about an economic slump.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison, Eshe Nelson and Isabella Simonetti

item.title: The Fed Appears More Optimistic Than Some Investors. Here’s Why.
item.description: In some corners of the market, investors just don’t see how the Federal Reserve can lower inflation without risking high unemployment.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Analysts believe the Federal Reserve will have to shift gears and start lowering interest rates sooner than it is forecasting.

item.title: U.K. Government Goes Full Tilt on Tax Cuts and Free-Market Economics
item.description: The new administration’s plans are a break from the Boris Johnson era and represent a turn toward Thatcherism. The negative reaction from financial markets underscored the extent of the gamble.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson, Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain, second from left, and Chancellor of the Exchequer Kwasi Kwarteng, right, during a visit to a modular building manufacturing company, in Northfleet, England, on Friday.

item.title: Trump Lawyers Push to Limit Aides’ Testimony in Jan. 6 Inquiry
item.description: The former president’s legal team is seeking to invoke attorney-client and executive privilege over grand jury testimony after waves of subpoenas went out to witnesses.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A number of high-ranking officials in Donald J. Trump’s administration have received grand jury subpoenas as part of the Justice Department’s inquiry into efforts to overturn the election.

item.title: Trump Is Battling a N.Y. Law Used to Take on Corporate Giants
item.description: The lawsuit filed this week by the state’s attorney general, Letitia James, is based on the same statute that was used against Exxon Mobil, Juul and UBS.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, William K. Rashbaum and Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:description: Attorney General Letitia James of New York described the “broad and special powers” she is granted by a state law aimed at reining in corporate malfeasance.

item.title: Hilary Mantel, Prize-Winning Author Known for ‘Wolf Hall,’ Dies at 70
item.description: The two-time Booker Prize-winning author was known for “Wolf Hall” and two other novels based on the life of Thomas Cromwell.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Ellie Smith for The New York Times

item.title: Hilary Mantel Stared Down Her Past, and the World’s, With Steely Resolve
item.description: Hilary Mantel brought great precision to her writing, and asked the same of us in our reading.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Hilary Mantel “was unsentimental, forthright, unafraid of stating her sometimes fierce views.”

item.title: Lorne Michaels Discusses the ‘Year of Reinvention’ Coming to ‘S.N.L.’
item.description: The “Saturday Night Live” creator explains how the show is handling one of its biggest cast turnovers in decades and why he has no plans to retire.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:description: Lorne Michaels on the set of “Saturday Night Live,” where a major cast overhaul is underway this season.

item.title: McCarthy Pitches a G.O.P. Agenda With Broad Appeal
item.description: Weeks before the midterm elections, the House minority leader presented a platform of neutral-sounding ideas that he said would guide a Republican majority. The hard right was there to cheer him on.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, joined with other House Republicans to unveil their “Commitment to America” agenda in Monongahela, Pa.

item.title: Amid G.O.P. Cash Crunch, One Very Flush Ally May Soon Share the Wealth
item.description: Donald J. Trump, sitting on a huge campaign war chest, is eyeing a raft of television ads to help Republican candidates in the midterm elections, people familiar with the talks say.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s political committee, Save America, has raised $124 million since last year.

item.title: Constance Wu on Her Memoir, ‘Making a Scene,’ and How She’s Moving On
item.description: In her memoir, “Making a Scene,” the actress reveals her isolation, racism in her career and how she’s moving on.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force
item.media:credit: Amy Harrity for The New York Times

item.title: The World’s Most Prestigious Art Exhibition Is Over. Maybe Forever.
item.description: The German mega-show Documenta closes this weekend. Whatever comes next, it will never be what it was before.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The columns of the Fridericianum Museum, one of Documenta’s main exhibition spaces, wrapped with a work by the Romanian artist Dan Perjovschi.

item.title: This Threat to Democracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Trump and his allies are trying to take over the machinery of American elections.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by Stephen Maturen, via Getty Images

item.title: How Do You Handle a Wounded Putin?
item.description: You push him back in Ukraine, but slowly.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks

item.title: Putin Will Get Whatever Result He Wants
item.description: Starting on Friday, people in four occupied regions of Ukraine will “vote” on whether to become a part of Russia. Here’s what that really means.
item.dc:creator: Sasha Vasilyuk
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in a police station in Kupiansk, Ukraine, depicts a Russian soldier and a woman holding a Soviet flag.

item.title: Stop Making Asian Americans Pay the Price for Campus Diversity
item.description: Affirmative action in admissions may be nearing its end. It’s about time.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter

item.title: I Don’t Need My Life to Be Remarkable
item.description: I’ve come to see the wisdom in not just seeking, but finding, joy in the mundane.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wildman

item.title: Biden Has Helped the Quiet Revolution of Giving People Money
item.description: Dozens of pilot programs and the success of the Child Tax Credit show the merits of a guaranteed income.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: The Wrong Trump Judge at the Right Time Can Wreak Havoc
item.description: To solve the problem of hyperpartisan judges, expand the federal judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: What We Will Miss Most About Roger Federer
item.description: His legacy is not reflected in just his career stats.
item.dc:creator: Michael Steinberger
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Residents of Luhansk, Ukraine, voted in a referendum organized by Russian authorities on Friday. Polling stations were installed across Russian-occupied Ukrainian territory for referendums on annexation by Russia.

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends an old animated favorite, a twisty new romantic thriller and a throwback reality show.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.media:description: The play’s the thing on the season premiere of “Bob’s Burgers.”

item.title: The Life and Times of Jann Wenner and Rolling Stone
item.description: Joe Hagan discusses “Sticky Fingers,” his 2017 biography of Wenner, and a panel of Times critics talks about their 2019 list of outstanding memoirs.

item.title: Are You Finally Back in the Office? Tell Us How You’re Managing
item.description: For those who worked from home for two-and-a-half years and are only now returning to an office, an entire lifestyle needs to be undone or readjusted. We want to hear about it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Grand Central Station in New York City.

item.title: Elton John, a Favorite of Trump, to Perform at the Biden White House
item.description: Such a performance by the British pop superstar was what President Biden’s predecessor had sought but never received.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Elton John is on a lengthy tour of the United States, with stops including Philadelphia in July.

item.title: Celtics Say Suspending Coach Ime Udoka Was a Matter of ‘Conscience’
item.description: The Celtics said Udoka violated unspecified team rules, prompting a one-year suspension.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Boston Celtics Coach Ime Udoka has been suspended for the 2022-23 season.

item.title: ‘Sobering’ Study Shows Challenges of Egg Freezing
item.description: Data from a fertility center showed many women did not get pregnant because of the age at which they froze their eggs and because they did not preserve enough of them.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Andre Chung for The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Eggs under a microscope at a fertility clinic in Maryland. “I always tell patients, ‘There’s not a baby in the freezer. There’s a chance to get pregnant,’ ” said one fertility expert.

item.title: Shy Raccoons Are Better Learners Than Bold Ones, Study Finds
item.description: Wildlife management strategies focused on aggressive raccoons may be inadvertently boosting the proportion of more clever ones in cities.
item.dc:creator: Betsy Mason

item.title: Is It Covid or the Flu? How to Tell Symptoms Apart
item.description: There are slight differences in symptoms, but the best way to tell which infection you have is through a test.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Fall Is the Season for Building Mindfulness and Resilience
item.description: Yes, the easy summer days are behind us. But if you’re willing to brave the chill, autumn holds a special set of rewards.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: Is It Possible to Exercise Too Much?
item.description: And if so, how can I tell if I’m overdoing it?
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: How a 79-year-old Film Director Learned to “Fly” on a Trapeze
item.description: Tom Moore made a name for himself as a film, TV and theater director. But his dream has always been to “fly” on the trapeze, high in the air. And that’s what he is doing at age 79.
item.dc:creator: Abby Ellin

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
